entry.title: Multiplicity Study of Exoplanet Host Stars
entry.summary: We present recent results of our ongoing multiplicity study of exoplanet host stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 3 figures

entry.title: The Orbital Period of Three Cataclysmic Variables from WASP Data
entry.summary: The publicly available WASP data are analysed to determine the orbital periods of the cataclysmic variables V378 Peg, SDSS J171456.78+585128.3 and ASAS 150946-2147.7.
entry.arxiv:comment: Accepted for publication in JAAVSO

entry.title: Asteroseismology observations and space missions
entry.summary: Contribution to a book entitled "Extraterrestrial seismology".
entry.arxiv:comment: 32 pages, 8 figures, 1 table

entry.title: The relations between main stellar parameters
entry.summary: The relations between masses, radii and surface temperatures of stars are considered. It is shown that calculated values of these relations are in a satisfactory agreement with measuring data.

entry.title: The plasma mechanism of stabilization of neutron-excess nuclei in stars
entry.summary: The mechanism of stabilization of neutron-excess nuclei in stars is considered. This mechanism must produce the neutronisation process in hot stars in the same way as it occurs in the dwarfs.

entry.title: Three-color Photoelectric Observations of UU Cas
entry.summary: Results of three-color photoelectric UBV observations of UU Cas performed at Abastumani Astrophysical Observatory in 1972-1984 are presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 19 pages, 1 figare

entry.title: Results of UBV Photoelectric Observations of the Early-Type Eclipsing Binary System XZ Cep
entry.summary: Results of the three-colour photoelectric observation of the close binary system XZ Cep, obtained at the Abastumani Astrophysical observatory, are presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 23 pages, 3 figures, 1 teble

entry.title: Linear Solar Models: a simple tool to investigate the properties of solar interior
entry.summary: We describe a simple method to study the dependence of the solar properties on a generic (small) modification the physical inputs adopted in standard solar models calculations.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, proceeding of the TAUP09 Workshop

entry.title: New Common Proper Motion Pairs Containing White Dwarfs from SDSS Data
entry.summary: Spectroscopically identified white dwarfs from the SDSS data release 1 are matched against SDSS data release 1 proper motion survey in the search for common proper motion companions
entry.arxiv:comment: withdrawn

entry.title: The Magnetic Sun: Reversals and Long-Term Variations
entry.summary: A didactic introduction to current thinking on some aspects of the solar dynamo is given for geophysicists and planetary scientists.
entry.arxiv:comment: 17 pages, 9 figures; Space Science Rev., in press

entry.title: David vs. Goliath: pitfalls and prospects in abundance analyses of dwarf vs. giant stars
entry.summary: I review some of the current limitations in modelling stellar atmospheres of solar-type stars and approaches to overcome them.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 1 two-panel figure, write-up of a talk given at NIC XI, Heidelberg, July 2010

entry.title: New Double-Mode and Other RR Lyrae Stars from WASP Data
entry.summary: 42 RRab, 46 RRc and 7 previously unidentified double-mode RR Lyrae stars were found in the publicly available data of the WASP archive. The Galactic double-mode RR Lyrae stars appear to show a bimodal period distribution.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published as IBVS 5955

entry.title: Statistical studies of Galactic open clusters I. Structural and basic astrophysical parameters
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author because has been send to other journal.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn

entry.title: Effects of Rotation on Stellar p-Mode Frequencies
entry.summary: Effects of stellar rotation on adiabatic oscillation frequencies of pressure modes are discussed. Methods to evaluate them are briefly exposed and some of their main results are presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 55 pages, 3 figures

entry.title: Results of UBV Photoelectric Observations of eclipsing binary RY Sct
entry.summary: Results of the three-colour photoelectric observation of the close binary system RY Sct, obtained at the Abastumani Astrophysical observatory, are presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 30 pages, 1 figure, 1 table

entry.title: Leo5 Is a Z Cam Type Dwarf Nova
entry.summary: Photometry of Leo5 = 1H 1025+220 show that it is a dwarf nova of the Z Cam subtype. Two long standstills have been observed in the last five years.
entry.arxiv:comment: Accepted for publication in JAAVSO

entry.title: Seismic diagnostics for rotating massive main sequence stars
entry.summary: Effects of stellar rotation on adiabatic oscillation frequencies of $\beta$ Cephei star are discussed. Methods to evaluate them are briefly described and some of the main results for four specific stars are presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 36 pages, 11 figures

entry.title: Symbiotic stars: Observations confront theory
entry.summary: In this paper, I present and discuss some recent observational results which may have important implications for our understanding of late phases of binary evolution.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 3 figures; to appear in the proceedings of the Asiago Workshop on Symbiotic Stars, A. Siviero and U. Munari eds., Baltic Astronomy special issue

entry.title: Siphon flow in a cool magnetic loop
entry.summary: We investigate the properties of a structure in the solar chromosphere in an active region to find out whether the feature is consistent with a siphon flow in a magnetic loop filled with chromospheric material.

entry.title: A Note on the Variability of V538 Cassiopeiae
entry.summary: CCD observations of V538 Cas have been made on nine nights during three weeks using the AAVSO Bright Star Monitor. No significant variations were found.
entry.arxiv:comment: To be published in The Journal of the American Association Of Variable Star Observers (JAAVSO)

entry.title: Neutrino flavour conversion and supernovae
entry.summary: We summarize the recent developments in our understanding of neutrino flavour conversion in core-collapse supernovae and discuss open questions.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings to the "Eleventh Conference on the Intersections of Particle and Nuclear Physics (CIPANP2012)", May 29 to June 3, Florida, 8 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: Helicity--vorticity turbulent pumping of magnetic fields in the solar dynamo
entry.summary: The interaction of helical convective motions and differential rotation in the solar convection zone results in turbulent drift of a large-scale magnetic field. We discuss the pumping mechanism and its impact on the solar dynamo.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, IAU 294 Proceedings

entry.title: Magnetic field of Vega
entry.summary: Recent spectropolarimetric observations of Vega have revealed a weak magnetic field. I present here the results of spectropolarimetric study of Vega during 37 nights from 1997 to 2012
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 3 figures. To appear in the conference proceedings "Putting A Stars into Context: Evolution, Environment, and Related Stars" held in Moscow, 2013

entry.title: The hot spot in HT Cas during its Superoutburst
entry.summary: We present the analysis of eclipses observed in dwarf nova HT Cas during its superoutburst in November 2010. Detection of hot spot was confirmed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, accepted for publication in Contrib. Astron. Obs. Skalnate Pleso

entry.title: Introduction to the Theory of Stellar Evolution
entry.summary: In this chapter we briefly review the basics of the theory of stellar evolution.
entry.arxiv:comment: Chapter 1, in Ecology of Blue Straggler Stars, H.M.J. Boffin, G. Carraro & G. Beccari (Eds), Astrophysics and Space Science Library, Springer

entry.title: Spectropolarimetry of massive stars: Requirements and potential from today to 2030
entry.summary: We develop the requirements and potential of spectropolarimetry as applied to understanding the physics of massive stars during the immediate, intermediate-term and long-term future.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of IAUS 307: New windows on massive stars: asteroseismology, interferometry, and spectropolarimetry

entry.title: Surface rotation of solar-like oscillating stars
entry.summary: In this work, we use different methods to extract the surface rotation rate of Kepler targets showing solar-like oscillations.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of the SF2A 2014 Conference, 3 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Extracting surface rotation periods of solar-like Kepler targets
entry.summary: We use various method to extract surface rotation periods of Kepler targets exhibiting solar-like oscillations and compare their results.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of the CoRoT3-KASC7 Conference. 2 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Soft X-ray microflares
entry.summary: Soft X-ray solar bursts are studied. Weak bursts with powers up to 10-8 W/m2 were detected. All the events were confirmed by GOES observations. Parameters of these microflares are determined. A physical mechanism for the low-intensity solar events is discussed.

entry.title: Rotating Hot White Dwarfs
entry.summary: We consider the effects of rotation and temperature on the structure of white dwarfs in order to compare them with the estimated data from observations.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: SS 433: O I lines and the circumbinary disk
entry.summary: Atomic oxygen emission at 8446 Angstroms traces the stable circumbinary disk undisturbed through an optical outburst and accompanying radio flare
entry.arxiv:comment: An informal note ... to inform. 3 pages

entry.title: On period ratios in modulated double-mode RR Lyrae stars
entry.summary: With the help of linear pulsation models we briefly discuss the peculiar period ratios characteristic for modulated double-mode RR Lyrae stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: RRL2015 conference, to appear in the Communications from the Konkoly Observatory of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Communications from the Konkoly Observatory, vol. 105, 69-72 (2016)

entry.title: The Blazhko Effect
entry.summary: We review the recent progress in our understanding of the Blazhko effect in RR Lyrae stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited talk; to be published in the Proceedings of the XXXVII Meeting of the Polish Astronomical Society
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Proceedings of the Polish Astronomical Society, vol. 3, pp. 22-30 (2016)

entry.title: The EXor phenomenon
entry.summary: Recent results obtained for the eruptive variables (EXors) are reviewed. These data span from X-rays to the sub-mm band and are presented along with perspectives for future observations achievable with the new advanced instrumentation.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published in the "Perspective" section of the Star Formation Newsletter (edited by Bo Reipurth)

entry.title: My Favorite Object L1551 IRS 5
entry.summary: The L1551-IRS 5 source and its associated atomic jet and molecular outflow has been studied for over 40 years. In this overview of the source this fascinating object and its properties are reviewed and its importance today is re-evaluated.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages 6 figures

entry.title: FO Aqr time keeping
entry.summary: Twelve seasons, from 2004 to 2015, of photometric monitoring of the intermediate polar FO Aqr are presented and are compared with previous observations. The ambiguities in the cycle counting can be lifted and a new O-C diagram, spanning 34 yr, is presented, along with new ephemerides.

entry.title: Star clusters: Anything but simple
entry.summary: The heated debate on the importance of stellar rotation and age spreads in massive star clusters has just become hotter by throwing stellar variability into the mix.
entry.arxiv:comment: Nature Astronomy, News & Views article (invited); published in the inaugural January 2017 issue

entry.title: OGLE Cepheids and RR Lyrae Stars in the Milky Way
entry.summary: We present new large samples of Galactic Cepheids and RR Lyrae stars from the OGLE Galaxy Variability Survey.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 6 figures. Proceedings of the 22nd Los Alamos Stellar Pulsation Conference: "Wide-Field Variability Surveys: a 21st-century Perspective"

entry.title: Plasma Magnetosphere Formation Around Oscillating Magnetized Neutron Stars
entry.summary: The notion of death line of rotating pulsars is applied to model of oscillating neutron stars. It is shown that the magnetosphere of typical non-rotating oscillating stars may not contain secondary plasma to support the generation of radio emission in the region of open field lines of plasma magnetosphere.
entry.arxiv:comment: Accepted for publication in Astrophysics & Space Science

entry.title: Search for sdB/WD pulsators in the Kepler FOV
entry.summary: In this article we present the preliminary results of an observational search for subdwarf B and white dwarf pulsators in the Kepler field of view, performed using the DOLORES camera attached to the 3.6m Telescopio Nazionale Galileo (TNG).
entry.arxiv:comment: Communications in Asteroseismology, in press; 2 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: On the Amplitudes of Superhumps
entry.summary: Amplitudes of bolometric light curves produced by 2D and 3D simulations are used to determine the corresponding visual amplitudes. They turn out to be about 10 times lower than typical amplitudes of superhumps. This means a major failure of the tidal model of superhumps.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, submitted to "Acta Astronomica"

entry.title: Are disk in dwarf novae during their superoutbursts really eccentric?
entry.summary: The evidence presented earlier by several authors for the substantial disk eccentricity in dwarf novae during their superoutbursts is shown to result either from errors or from arbitrary, incorrect assumptions. In particular, the evidence resulting from hot spot eclipses was based on the assumption that the spot distances are identical with disk radii which is not always correct.
entry.arxiv:comment: 13 pages, 5 figures, submitted to "Acta Astronomica"

entry.title: On the emission polarization of RX J1856.5-3754
entry.summary: The polarization properties of RX J1856.5-3754 are investigated, based on the plasma emission model presented in previous works. It is shown that if the emission of this source is generated by the synchrotron mechanism, the X-ray and the optical emission are linearly polarized and the corresponding degrees of linear polarization are calculated. The measurement of the polarization patterns of this source appears to be most reliable way, to make clear its real emission nature.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: CN-Cycle Neutrinos and Solar Metalicity
entry.summary: We discuss the current Standard Solar Model conflict between helioseismology and photospheric abundances, a speculation that connects this anomaly to formation of the gaseous giant planets, and a possible neutrino measurement to directly test solar core metalicity.
entry.arxiv:comment: Talk presented at PANIC08, Eilat, Israel. Four pages, two figures

entry.title: A Review of AGB Mass Loss Imaging Techniques
entry.summary: Circumstellar imaging, across the electromagnetic spectrum, allows to derive fundamental diagnostics for the physics of mass loss in the AGB phase. I review the current status of the field, with particular emphasis on the techniques that provide the strongest constraints for mass loss modeling efforts.
entry.arxiv:comment: accepted for publication in the Publications of the Astronomical Society of Australia

entry.title: An Exact Test of Generalized Ray Theory in Local Helioseismology
entry.summary: Generalized Ray Theory (GRT) provides a simple description of MHD mode transmission and conversion between magnetoacoustic fast and slow waves and is directly applicable to solar active regions. Here it is tested in a simple two-dimensional, isothermal, gravitationally-stratified model with inclined magnetic field using previously published exact solutions and found to perform very well.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 pages, 4 figures

entry.title: Acceleration Mechanisms
entry.summary: Glossary I. Background and context of the subject II. Stochastic acceleration III. Resonant scattering IV. Diffusive shock acceleration V. DSA at multiple shocks VI. Applications of DSA VII. Acceleration by parallel electric fields VIII. Other acceleration mechanisms IX. Future directions X. Appendix: Quasilinear equations XI. Bibliography
entry.arxiv:comment: To be published in Meyers, Robert (Ed.) Encyclopedia of complexity and systems science, Springer review completed late 2007

entry.title: Coherent Emission
entry.summary: The theory of plasma emission and of electron cyclotron maser emission, and their applications to solar radio bursts and to Jupiter's DAM and the Earth's AKR are reviewed, emphasizing the early literature and problems that remain unresolved. It is pointed out that there are quantitative measures of coherence in radio astronomy that have yet to be explored either observationally or theoretically.
entry.arxiv:comment: to be published in Proceedings of IAU Symposium 257 Universal Heliophysical Processes, N. Gopalswamy & D.F. Webb eds

entry.title: Neutrino fluxes from CNO cycle in the Sun in the non stationary case with mixing
entry.summary: The computational analyses is presented of the non stationary case with mixing of the solar model when the neutrino flux $F_{13}$ from the decay of $^{13}N$ is higher than a standard solar model predicts
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 3figures

entry.title: Z Cha and its Superhumps
entry.summary: From the analysis of superhump eclipses of Z Cha it is found that the location of the superhump light source coincides with the overflowing parts of the stream. This implies that superhumps are due to modulated mass transfer rate resulting in periodically enhanced dissipation of the kinetic energy of the stream.
entry.arxiv:comment: 12 pages, 8 figures, submitted to "Acta Astronomica"

entry.title: New Interpretation of Superhumps
entry.summary: Observational evidence is presented for periodically variable irradiation of secondary components. This results in strongly modulated mass outflow. Superhumps are then due to enhanced dissipation of the kinetic energy of the stream. Qualitative interpretation of superhump periods and their variations is also presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 pages, 2 figures, submitted to "Acta Astronomica"

entry.title: Unsolved Problems about Supernovae
entry.summary: A number of unsolved problems and open questions about the nature and the properties of supernovae are identified and briefly discussed. Some suggestions and directions toward possible solutions are also considered.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, Proceedings of 'Probing Stellar Populations out to the Distant Universe', Cefalu, Italy, Sep 7-19, 2008, AIP Conf. Proc. Series

entry.title: Unveiling the phenomenon of Double Periodic Variables
entry.summary: In this paper we give a brief report of our recent research on Double Periodic Variables (DPVs), including the discovery of DPVs in the Galaxy and some insights on the nature of their long-cycle variability.

author.name: R. E. Mennickent
author.arxiv:affiliation: Departamento de Astronomia, Universidad de Concepcion, Chile

author.name: Z. Kolaczkowski
author.arxiv:affiliation: Departamento de Astronomia, Universidad de Concepcion, Chile
Instytut Astronomiczny Uniwersytetu Wroclawskiego, Wroclaw, Poland

entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in "Proceedings of the XII Reunion Latinoamericana de la UIA", Revista Mexicana de Astronomia y Astrofisica, in press

entry.title: Model of two-fluid reconnection
entry.summary: A theoretical model of quasi-stationary, two-dimensional magnetic reconnection is presented in the framework of incompressible two-fluid magnetohydrodynamics (MHD). The results are compared with recent numerical simulations and experiment.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 1 figure, accepted to Physical Review Letters

entry.title: Infrared interferometry of massive young stellar objects
entry.summary: We discuss VLTI AMBER and MIDI interferometry in addition to single-dish Subaru observations of massive young stellar objects. The observations probe linear size scales between 10 to 1000 AU for the average distance of our sources.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, contributed talk to the ESO workshop "The Interferometric view on Hot Stars", March 2-6, 2009, Vina del Mar, Chile

entry.title: Fundamental Stellar Astrophysics Revealed at Very High Angular Resolution
entry.summary: A short review of recent results in long-baseline optical interferometry pertaining to fundamental stellar parameters and the future possibilities this area over the next decade. Included are discussions of accurate stellar masses, links between asteroseismology and interferometry, precise radii and effective temperatures, limb darkening and convection, stellar rotation, and high angular resolution imaging.
entry.arxiv:comment: 14 pages, 5 figures, white paper submitted to the Astro2010 Decadal Survey

entry.title: Astrophysical constraints on unparticle-inspired models of gravity
entry.summary: We use stellar dynamics arguments to constrain the relevant parameters of ungravity inspired models. We show that resulting bounds do constrain the parameters of the theory of unparticles, as far as its energy scale satisfies the condition $\Lambda \geq 1 TeV$ and $d$ is close to unity.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 4 figures

entry.title: The Binary History and the Magnetic Field of Neutron Star
entry.summary: There has been strong observational evidence suggesting a causal connection between the binary history of neutron stars and the evolution of their magnetic field. In this article we discuss one of the plausible mechanisms proposed for the evolution of the surface magnetic field, that of the diamagnetic screening of the field by accreted material.
entry.arxiv:comment: This article, published in 2003, is somewhat inaccessible

entry.title: Solar Forcing on the Changing Climate
entry.summary: The influence of solar cycle and activity phenomena on the two climatic variabilities such as the rainfall and the surface temperature of the Indian subcontinent are critically examined. It is concluded from this study that the sun indeed strongly influences both of these climatic variabilities and the sun's influence simply cannot be ignored.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages

entry.title: Wind structure in late-B supergiants
entry.summary: Extended spectroscopic datasets of several late-B stars of luminosity class Ia revealed the presence of similar peculiarities in their H alpha profiles, which might be interpreted as indications of deviation from spherically symmetric, smooth wind approximation. Surface structures due to non-radial pulsations or weak, large-scale, dipole magnetic fields might be responsible for creating wind structure in the envelopes of these stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contribution to the third conference of the Bulgarian Astronomical Society. Published in Bulgarian Astronomical Journal, Vol. 10

entry.title: Intrinsic color indices and luminosity sequences of stars in the 2MASS two-color diagram
entry.summary: Intrinsic sequences of luminosity V and III stars in the J-H vs. H-Ks diagram of the 2MASS system are determined using about 1250 unreddened and dereddened stars. Intrinsic color indices for MK spectral classes are tabulated and compared with the results in other JHK systems.
entry.arxiv:comment: 13 pages, 8 figures, 3 tables

entry.title: A possible mechanism of energy dissipation in the front of a shock wave driven ahead of a coronal mass ejection
entry.summary: Mark 4 and LASCO C2, C3 coronagraph data analysis shows that, up to the distance $R\sim$ 5 R$_\odot$ from the center of the Sun, the thickness of a CME-generated shock front may be of order of the proton mean free path. This means that the energy dissipation mechanism in a shock front at these distances is collisional.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 figures

entry.title: gamma Doradus stars in the COROT exoplanets fields: first inspection
entry.summary: We present here preliminary results concerning 32 stars identified as main gamma Doradus candidates by the COROT Variable Classifier (CVC) among the 4 first fields of the exoplanet CCDs.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in "Stellar Pulsation: Challenges for Theory and Observation", AIP

entry.title: Disentangling of spectra - theory and practice
entry.summary: In this document a review of the author's method of Fourier disentangling of spectra of binary and multiple stars is presented for the purpose of the summer school organized at Ondrejov observatory in September 2008. Related methods are also discussed and some practical hints for the use of the author's code KOREL and related auxiliary codes with examples are given.

entry.title: Light Curves of Galactic Eclipsing Double Periodic Variables
entry.summary: We present results of the investigation of the nature of double periodic variables (DPVs). We have selected a sample of Galactic eclipsing DPVs for a multiwavelength photometric study aimed to reveal their nature. The short orbital periodicity and the cyclic variability are decoupled and separately investigated. Shapes of orbital light curves are consistent with semi-detached binaries. The amplitude of the long cycle is always larger in redder bandpasses.

entry.title: Neutrinos from CNO cycle at the present epoch of the solar neutrino research
entry.summary: The importance of the study of solar neutrinos generated in CNO cycle is discussed in view of the presently obtained data. The emphasis is given to the precise detemination of the flux of low energy pp-neutrinos as a main topic of future experimental program.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 2 Figures, Contribution for Proceedings of the Erice School 2009 in "Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics"

entry.title: Surface temperature maps for II Peg during 1999-2002
entry.summary: The active RS CVn star II Peg has been spectroscopically monitored for almost 18 years with the SOFIN spectrograph at NOT, La Palma, Spain. In this paper we present five new surface temperature maps of the object for the years 1999 (two maps), 2001 (one map) and 2002 (two maps).

entry.title: Pulsar timing array projects
entry.summary: Pulsars are amongst the most stable rotators known in the Universe. Over many years some millisecond pulsars rival the stability of atomic clocks. Comparing observations of many such stable pulsars may allow the first direct detection of gravitational waves, improve the Solar System planetary ephemeris and provide a means to study irregularities in terrestrial time scales. Here we review the goals and status of current and future pulsar timing array projects.
entry.arxiv:comment: To be published in IAU261 proceedings

entry.title: The Study of Magnetically Deformed Atoms in the Outer Crust of Neutron Stars in Presence of Strong Quantizing Magnetic Field
entry.summary: We have studied the various properties of magnetically deformed atoms, replaced by deformed Wigner-Seitz cells, at the outer crust region of strongly magnetized neutron stars (magnetars) using a relativistic version of Thomas-Fermi model in cylindrical coordinates.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages REVTEX file, 14 .eps figures

entry.title: Concluding remarks on Solar and Stellar Activities and related planets
entry.summary: The symposium has shown the dynamism of this rapidly evolving discipline. I shall concentrate here on some highlights and some complementary informations. I conclude on open questions with some perspectives on solar & stellar activity and related planets.
entry.arxiv:comment: 17 pages, 13 figures, concluding remarks of IAU264 in RIO, 2009

entry.title: Seismic signature of helium ionization in the Sun and stars
entry.summary: We present a summary of an asteroseismic signature of helium ionization reported by Houdek & Gough (2007, 2008, 2009) for low-degree p modes in solar-type stars, and illustrate its applications for asteroseismic diagnoses.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proc. HELAS Workshop on `New insights into the Sun', eds M. Cunha, M. Thompson, (invited talk)

entry.title: The timing behaviour of radio pulsars
entry.summary: The purpose of this review paper is to summarise the pulsar timing method, to provide an overview of recent research into the spin-down of pulsars over decadal timescales and to highlight the science that can be achieved using high-precision timing of millisecond pulsars.
entry.arxiv:comment: o appear in Proceedings for "Compact stars in the QCD phase diagram II (CSQCD II), May 20-24, 2009, KIAA at Peking University, Beijing - P. R. China [http://vega.bac.pku.edu.cn/rxxu/csqcd.htm]

entry.title: Signal delay analysis for binary pulsars
entry.summary: This note gives a correction to the standard analysis of the delay pattern in the radio signals from a pulsar in a binary system; the same coordinate frame should be used for the transmission of the signal as for the motion of the pulsar in the field of its companion.

entry.title: Open issues in stellar modelling
entry.summary: An important goal of helio- and asteroseismology is to improve the modelling of stellar evolution. Here I provide a brief discussion of some of the uncertain issues in stellar modelling, of possible relevance to asteroseismic inferences.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proc. HELAS Workshop on `New insights into the Sun', eds M. S. Cunha and M. J. Thompson (invited talk)

entry.title: 2-D MHD Configurations for Accretion Disks Around Magnetized Stars
entry.summary: We discuss basic features of steady accretion disk morphology around magnetized compact astrophysical objects. A comparison between the standard model of accretion based on visco-resistive MHD and the plasma instabilities, like ballooning modes, triggered by very low value of resistivity, is proposed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, 1 figure, presentation given at the Marcel Grossman Meeting XII, July 12 - 18 2009 (Paris)

entry.title: Turbulent Mixing in Stars: Theoretical Hurdles
entry.summary: A program is outlined, and first results described, in which fully three-dimensional, time dependent simulations of hydrodynamic turbulence are used as a basis for theoretical investigation of the physics of turbulence in stars. The inadequacy of the treatment of turbulent convection as a diffusive process is discussed. A generalization to rotation and magnetohydrodynamics is indicated, as are connection to simulations of 3D stellar atmospheres.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 1 figure, IAU Symposium 265, 2009

entry.title: Neutrinos in dense quark matter and cooling of compact stars
entry.summary: We discuss that observational constraints on neutrino cooling processes may restrict the spectrum of quark matter phases admissible for compact star interiors.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, contribution to International School of Nuclear Physics on "Neutrinos in Cosmology, in Astro-, Particle- and Nuclear Physics, Erice-Sicily, September 16-24, 2009

entry.title: The contact system V566 Ophiuchi revisited
entry.summary: New CCD photometric observations of the eclipsing binary V566 Oph have been obtained. The light curves are analyzed with the Wilson-Devinney code and new geometric and photometric elements are derived. A new O-C analysis of the system is presented and apparent period changes are discussed with respect to possible Light-Time Effect in the system.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 4 figures, contribution to the conference proceedings: The 9th Hellenic Astronomical Conference, Athens, Hellas, 20-24 Sep.2009

entry.title: Comment on `Oblique Propagation and Dissipation of Alfv√©n Waves in Coronal Holes' by Srivastava and Dwivedi
entry.summary: We comment on the recent paper by Srivastava and Dwivedi (J. Astrophs. Astr. {\bf 28}, 1, 2007). In the said paper the derived dispersion relation $\nu \eta \cos^4 \theta k^4 + [v_A^2 - i \omega (\nu + \eta)] \cos^2 \theta k^2 - \omega^2 = 0$ seems to be in error. Consequently, the conclusion drawn in their paper are not reliable.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages

entry.title: Hanle signatures of the coronal magnetic field in the linear polarization of the hydrogen LyAlpha line
entry.summary: This paper is dedicated to the assessment of the validity of future coronal spectro-polarimetric observations and to prepare their interpretation in terms of the magnetic field vector.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 7 figures. in press in Astronomy and Astrophysics

entry.title: Molecular astronomy of cool stars and sub-stellar objects
entry.summary: The optical and infrared spectra of a wide variety of `cool' astronomical objects including the Sun, sunspots, K-, M- and S-type stars, carbon stars, brown dwarfs and extrasolar planets are reviewed. The review provides the necessary astronomical background for chemical physicists to understand and appreciate the unique molecular environments found in astronomy. The calculation of molecular opacities needed to simulate the observed spectral energy distributions is discussed.

entry.title: On the mass transfer rate in SS Cyg
entry.summary: The mass transfer rate in SS Cyg at quiescence, estimated from the observed luminosity of the hot spot, is log\dotM_tr=16.8+/-0.3. This is safely below the critical mass transfer rates of log\dotM_crit=18.1 (corresponding to logT^o_crit=3.88) or log\dotM_crit=17.2 (corresponding to the "revised value of logT^o_crit=3.65). The mass transfer rate during outbursts is strongly enhanced.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 1 figure. submitted to Acta Astronomica

entry.title: The Polar CSS 081231:071126+440405 at a Low Accretion Rate
entry.summary: Time-resolved photometry of the eclipsing polar CSS 081231:071126+44040 was obtained with the Vatican Advanced Technology Telescope (VATT) on four nights in October 2009. The light curve shows a single accretion hotspot lagging 10 degrees behind the secondary. The last two nights of data show "sputtering" accretion and the hotspot nearly disappears in consecutive orbits.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 2 figures; IBVS Number 5923

entry.title: Some comments on the paper by Vink et al. 2009 (A&A, 505, 743 or arXiv:0909.0888)
entry.summary: In a recent paper, Vink et al. analyzed some spectropolarimetry data of O-type stars. Here we comment on our disagreement with some points presented in this paper, with the hope of helping to fully grasp the scientific implication of these measurements.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages

entry.title: The quiet chromosphere. Old wisdom, new insights, future needs
entry.summary: The introduction to this review summarizes chromosphere observation in two figures. The first part showcases the historical emphasis on the eclipse chromosphere in the development of NLTE line formation theory and criticizes 1D modeling. The second part advertises recent breakthroughs after many decades of standstill. The third part discusses what may or should come next.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in Proceedings 25th NSO Workshop, editors A. Tritschler, K. Reardon, H. Uitenbroek, Mem. Soc. Astr. Ital

entry.title: The Solar Orbiter mission and its prospects for helioseismology
entry.summary: Solar Orbiter is intended to become ESA's next solar mission in heritage of the successful SOHO project. The scientific objectives of the mission, its design, and its scientific payload are reviewed. Specific emphasis is given to the perspectives of Solar Orbiter with respect to helioseismology.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 4 figures

entry.title: Latitude migration of solar filaments
entry.summary: The Carte Synoptique catalogue of solar filaments from March 1919 to December 1989, corresponding to complete cycles 16 to 21 is utilized to show latitudinal migration of filaments at low latitudes (less than 50 deg), and the latitudinal drift of solar filaments in each hemisphere in each cycle of the time interval is compared with the corresponding drift of sunspot groups. The physical implication behind the latitudinal drift of filaments is explored.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages,5figures

entry.title: CSS091215:060708-060335 : An Optically Emergent Eruptive Near the Head of Herbig Haro 866 West
entry.summary: Optical data from the Catalina RealTime Transient Survey (CRTS) reveal an emergent eruptive in the embedded Infrared Star Cluster [C2001b] 11, within the Monoceros R2 Molecular Cloud.
entry.arxiv:comment: withdrawn
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Greaves J., (2010), Information Bulletin on Variable Stars, 5921, 1

entry.title: V5485 Sagittarii: A Possible Symbiotic Star Exhibiting Ellipsoidal Variation Evidence as Orbital Signature
entry.summary: MACHO project photometry shows the candidate Symbiotic Star V5485 Sagittarii's red giant component has a photometric orbital period of 270 days as evidenced by ellipsoidal variation of the lightcurve.
entry.arxiv:comment: withdrawn
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Greaves, J., (2009), Peremennye Zvezdy Prilozhenie, vol.9, no. 13

entry.title: Ellipsoidal effect in the symbiotic star YY Her
entry.summary: A new estimation of the orbital period of YY Her on the base of our and published observations is presented. Phased light curves in RI bands show evidently ellipsoidal effect connected with the tidal distortion of the giant surface.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, Conference Binaries - key to comprehention of the Universe, Brno, Czech Republik

entry.title: A Common Proper Motion Companion to the Exoplanet Host 51 Pegasi
entry.summary: The exoplanet host 51 Pegasi has a widely separated red dwarf companion. Two other, far more distant, stars are also co-moving with this star, showing that they are at least of common Galactic orbit due to a common origin.
entry.arxiv:comment: withdrawn

entry.title: Helioseismology over the solar cycle
entry.summary: Helioseismology has produced unprecedented measurements of the Sun's internal structure and dynamics over the past 25 years. Much of this work has been based on global helioseismology. Now local helioseismology too is showing its great promise. This review summarizes very briefly the principal global results that may be relevant to an understanding of the origins of solar magnetism. Recent results regarding the variation of frequencies over the solar cycle and the temporal variations of subsurface flows are briefly summarized.

entry.title: Updating the Historical Sunspot Record
entry.summary: We review the evidence for the argument that Rudolf Wolf's calibration of the Sunspot Number is likely to be correct and that Max Waldmeier introduced an upwards jump in the sunspot number in 1945. The combined effect of these adjustments suggests that there has been no secular change in the sunspot number since coming out of the Maunder Minimum ~1700.
entry.arxiv:comment: SOHO23 Conference Proceedings, Astronomical Society of the Pacific

entry.title: The Importance of Fundamental Taxonomic Principles for Sensible Underpinning of Epoch Photometry Datasets
entry.summary: The dangers inherent in the utilisation of easily available and readily analysed datasets in tandem with "blackbox" software applications without supporting taxonomic understanding and data nature familiarity is exemplified via examination of a misrepresentation of the results from a DEBIL analysis of OGLE II Galactic Bulge candidate variables.
entry.arxiv:comment: Withdrawn by arXiv-admin due to inappropriate use of AN formatting

entry.title: Radiative transfer in stellar atmospheres
entry.summary: This review presents basic equations for the solution of the NLTE radiative transfer problem for trace elements and methods for its solution are summarized. The importance of frequency coupling in radiative transfer in stellar atmospheres is emphasized.
entry.arxiv:comment: presented at the workshop held in Nice, France, 30.7.-4.8.2007, to appear in Non-LTE Line Formation for Trace Elements in Stellar Atmospheres, R. Monier et al. eds., EAS Publ. Ser

entry.title: Statistical equilibrium equations for trace elements in stellar atmospheres
entry.summary: The conditions of thermodynamic equilibrium, local thermodynamic equilibrium, and statistical equilibrium are discussed in detail. The equations of statistical equilibrium and the supplementary equations are shown together with the expressions for radiative and collisional rates with the emphasize on the solution for trace elements.
entry.arxiv:comment: presented at the workshop held in Nice, France, 30.7.-4.8.2007, to appear in Non-LTE Line Formation for Trace Elements in Stellar Atmospheres, R. Monier et al. eds., EAS Publ.Ser

entry.title: An automated pipeline for asteroseismology based on the autocorrelation of stellar time series
entry.summary: The autocorrelation of an asteroseismic time series has been identified as a powerful tool capable of providing measurements of the large frequency separations. The performance of this method has been assessed and quantified by Mosser & Appourchaux (2009). We propose now an automated pipeline based on it and describe its performance.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of the HELAS workshop New insights into the Sun held in Ponte de Lima, 09/2009

entry.title: uvby-beta photoelectric photometry of Cepheid stars
entry.summary: We present time-series uvby-beta photometry of 41 classical Cepheid stars. A brief discussion of the comparison between the presented data and previous photometric data has been done.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 5 figures, 5 tables

entry.title: Convection and oscillations
entry.summary: In this short review on stellar convection dynamics I address the following, currently very topical, issues: (1) the surface effects of the Reynolds stresses and nonadiabaticity on solar-like pulsation frequencies, and (2) oscillation mode lifetimes of stochastically excited oscillations in red giants computed with different time-dependent convection formulations.
entry.arxiv:comment: Accepted for publication in Astronomische Nachrichten, HELA IV proceedings, T. Roca Cort\'es, P. Pall\'e, S. Jim\'enez Reyes, eds, 7 figures

entry.title: Recurrent flux emergence from dynamo-generated fields
entry.summary: We investigate the emergence of a large-scale magnetic field. This field is dynamo-generated by turbulence driven with a helical forcing function. Twisted arcade-like field structures are found to emerge in the exterior above the turbulence zone. Time series of the magnetic field structure show recurrent plasmoid ejections.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 2 figures, conference proceeding
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union (2010), 6: 407-408

entry.title: Reconstructing CMEs with Coordinated Imaging and In Situ Observations: Global Structure, Kinematics, and Implications for Space Weather Forecasting
entry.summary: See the pdf for details
entry.arxiv:comment: 45 pages, 16 figures, ApJ, in press

entry.title: Superfluid dynamics in neutron star crusts
entry.summary: A simple description of superfluid hydrodynamics in the inner crust of a neutron star is given. Particular attention is paid to the effect of the lattice of nuclei on the properties of the superfluid neutrons, and the effects of entrainment, the fact that some fraction of the neutrons are locked to the motion of the protons in nuclei.

entry.title: Masses of the astrometric SB2 Œ∂Ori A
entry.summary: We report the first dynamic mass for an O-type supergiant, the interferometrically resolved SB2 system \zeta Ori A (O9.5Ib+B0/1). The separation of the system excludes any previous mass-transfer, ensuring that the derived masses can be compared to single star evolutionary tracks.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, IAUS 272 - Active OB Stars: Structure, Evolution, Mass Loss and Critical Limits

entry.title: The resonant B1II+B1II binary BI108
entry.summary: BI108 is a luminous variable star in the Large Magellanic Cloud classified B1II. The variability consists of two resonant periods (3:2), of which only one is orbital, however. We discuss possible mechanisms responsible for the second period and its resonant locking.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, IAUS 272 - Active OB Stars: Structure, Evolution, Mass Loss and Critical Limits

entry.title: Helicity invariants of force-free field for a rectangular box
entry.summary: An algorithm for calculating three gauge-invariant helicities (self-, mutual- and Berger relative helicity) for a magnetic field specified in a rectangular box is described. The algorithm is tested on a well-known force-free model (Low and Lou, 1990) presented in vector-potential form.

entry.title: Eta Carinae long-term variability
entry.summary: We present preliminary results of our analysis on the long-term variations observed in the optical spectrum of the LBV star Eta Carinae. Based on the hydrogen line profiles, we conclude that the physical parameters of the primary star did not change in the last 15 years.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, IAUS 272 - Active OB Stars: Structure, Evolution, Mass Loss and Critical Limits

entry.title: The IACOB spectroscopic database of Northern Galactic OB stars
entry.summary: We present the IACOB spectroscopic database, an homogeneous set of high quality, high resolution spectra of Galactic O- and B-type stars obtained with the FIES spectrograph attached to the Nordic Optical Telescope. We also present some results from ongoing projects using the IACOB database.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 4 figues, 1 tables. Poster contribution to the proceedings of the LIAC2010 conference "The multi-wavelength view of hot, massive stars"

entry.title: Distribution of Magnetic Shear Angle in an Emerging Flux Region
entry.summary: We study the distribution of magnetic shear in an emerging flux region using the high-resolution Hinode/SOT SP observations. The distribution of mean magnetic shear angle across the active region shows large values near region of flux emergence i.e., in the middle of existing bipolar region and decreases while approaching the periphery of the active region.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, Proceedings of IAU Symposium 273 "Physics of Sun and Starspots" Eds. D.P. Choudhary and K.G. Strassmeier

entry.title: Using Absorptive Linear Polarization Spectroscopy to Understand Imbedded Stars
entry.summary: Sensitive measurements of the linearly polarized spectra of stars can be used to deduce geometric properties of their otherwise unresolved circumstellar environments. This paper describes some of the evidence for optical pumping and absorptive linear polarization and explores some interesting applications of linear spectropolarimetry for obtaining spatial information from imbedded stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 Pages, Accepted for ASP Conference Proceedings of the "Solar Polarization Workshop 6"

entry.title: Flaring Solar Hale Sector Boundaries
entry.summary: Magnetic fields and the occurrence of flares and microflares are strongly concentrated near that portion (the Hale boundary) in each solar hemisphere where the change in magnetic sector polarity is the same as that between leading and following sunspot polarities in active regions.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 pages; 4 figures

entry.title: The cool end of the DZ sequence in the SDSS
entry.summary: We report the discovery of cool DZ white dwarfs, which lie in the SDSS (u-g) vs. (g-r) two-color diagram across and below the main sequence. These stars represent the extension of the well-known DZ sequence towards cooler temperatures.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in the proceedings of the "17th European Workshop on White Dwarfs", Tuebingen, Germany, August 16-20, 2010

entry.title: Solar Flares and the Chromosphere
entry.summary: A white paper prepared for the Space Studies Board, National Academy of Sciences (USA), for its Decadal Survey of Solar and Space Physics (Heliophysics), reviewing and encouraging studies of flare physics in the chromosphere.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 3 figures

entry.title: Developing a pulsar-based timescale
entry.summary: We show how pulsar observations may be used to construct a time standard that is independent of terrestrial time standards. The pulsar time scale provides a method to determine the stability of terrestrial time standards over years to decades. Here, we summarise the method, provide initial results and discuss the possibilities and limitations of our pulsar time scale.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 page conference proceedings from Journees conference in Paris (20-22 Sept 2010)

entry.title: Symbiotic Novae
entry.summary: The symbiotic novae are thermonuclear novae in symbiotic binary systems -- interacting binaries with evolved red giant donors, and the longest orbital periods. This paper aims at presenting physical characteristics of these objects and discussing their place among the whole family of symbiotic stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 7 figures, The proceedings of the Physics of Accreting Compact Binaries

entry.title: Time-resolved spectroscopy of DROXO X-ray sources: Flares and FeKalpha emission
entry.summary: We present a systematic search for Fe Kalpha emission from young stellar objects of the rho Ophiuchi star forming region observed in the Deep Rho Ophiuchi XMM-Newton Observation (DROXO).
entry.arxiv:comment: Poster Proceedings Cool Stars 16

entry.title: Non-LTE Line Formation in the Near-IR: Hot Stars
entry.summary: Line-formation calculations in the Rayleigh-Jeans tail of the spectral energy distribution are complicated by an amplification of non-LTE effects. For hot stars this can make quantitative modelling of spectral lines in the near-IR challenging. An introduction to the modelling problems is given and several examples in the context of near-IR line formation for hydrogen and helium are discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 16 pages, 13 figures

entry.title: Power-law tails in triple system decay statistics
entry.summary: We have investigated the decay statistics of triple systems with different masses in Newtonial dynamics. We demonstrate that in a broad interval of mass ratios this statistics has good approximation by power-law tails. The power indices do not show any significant dependence on mass ratios.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 3 figures, 1 table

entry.title: Theory and Models of Colliding Stellar Winds
entry.summary: I discuss some of the important aspects of the phenomena of colliding winds in massive binary star systems with a particular focus on WR140.
entry.arxiv:comment: 11 pages, 5 figures, Published in proceedings of "Stellar Winds in Interaction", editors T. Eversberg and J.H. Knapen. Full proceedings volume is available on http://www.stsci.de/pdf/arrabida.pdf

entry.title: The search for progenitor models of type Ia supernovae
entry.summary: We show the preliminary results of our search for the progenitor systems of type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia). We model binary populations our aim being to compare these models with the observations of detailed element abundances of the hot Intra-Cluster Medium.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 2 figures, appeared in proceedings for "Binary Star Evolution: Mass Loss, Accretion and Mergers"

entry.title: A 116 Year Record of Mass Transfer in R Arae
entry.summary: This is a period study of the bright interacting southern eclipsing binary star R Arae. New photometric data are combined with archival data to determine R Ara's average mass transfer rate over the past 116 years through the analysis of the resulting ephemeris curve. An updated ephemeris is given.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 3 figures, accepted for publication in IBVS on Feb. 14, 2011
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Reed, P. A., 2011, Information Bulletin on Variable Stars, 5975

entry.title: Direct Evidence for Modulated Irradiation of Secondary Components in Dwarf Novae during Superoutbursts
entry.summary: Contribution from the irradiated secondary component is detected in the light curves of five dwarf novae observed during superoutbursts. Their superhump light curves show that irradiation is modulated with the superhump phase. This strengthens the new interpretation of superhumps (Smak 2009) as being due to irradiation controlled mass transfer rate resulting in modulated dissipation of the kinetic energy of the stream.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 6 figures; submitted to "Acta Astronomica"

entry.title: The origin of the solar magnetic cycle
entry.summary: After summarizing the relevant observational data, we discuss how a study of flux tube dynamics in the solar convection zone helps us to understand the formation of sunspots. Then we introduce the flux transport dynamo model and assess its success in modelling both the solar cycle and its departures from strictly periodic behaviour.
entry.arxiv:comment: 18 pages, 14 figures, Proceedings of Chandrasekhar Centenary Conference

entry.title: Electron capture rates in a plasma
entry.summary: A new general expression is derived for nuclear electron capture rates within dense plasmas. Its qualitative nature leads us to question some widely accepted assumptions about how to calculate the effects of the plasma on the rates. A perturbative evaluation, though not directly applicable to the strongly interacting case, appears to bear out these suspicions.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages

entry.title: The Eclipsing Cataclysmic Variables PHL 1445 and GALEX J003535.7+462353
entry.summary: PHL 1445 is found to be an eclipsing cataclysmic variable with an orbital period of 76.3 minutes. GALEX J003535.7+462353 is a new eclipsing dwarf nova with an orbital period of 4.13 hours. Both objects show deep eclipses with an amplitude of more than two magnitudes.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published as IBVS 5982

entry.title: Coronal Polarization
entry.summary: We present an overview of the physical mechanisms responsible for the coronal polarization at different wavelength regimes. We also review different techniques using coronal polarization to determine various quantities necessary for understanding the thermodynamic properties of the solar coronal plasma. This includes the coronal magnetic field, electronic densities, temperatures, velocities, etc. The future needs to acquire better information on the solar corona using polarization will be outlined.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 5 figures, 6th Solar Polarization Workshop

entry.title: MOST satellite photometry of Regulus
entry.summary: No eclipse has been found in 15 days of almost continuous photometry of Alpha Leo with accuracy of about 0.0005 mag.
entry.arxiv:comment: Submitted to the Inf. Bull. Var. Stars

entry.title: A formation mechanism for the type II radio emission in the solar corona unrelated to shock waves
entry.summary: Mark 4, COR1/STEREO and LASCO/SOHO data analysis shows that at least a portion of type II radio bursts observed in the corona occurs in the presence of a CME, but in the absence of a shock ahead of them. A drift current instability in the CME frontal structure is discussed as a possible cause of such bursts.

entry.title: Solution of NLTE Radiative Transfer Problems Using Forth-and-Back Implicit Lambda Iteration
entry.summary: The basic idea of an extremely fast convergent iterative method, the Forth-and-Back Implicit Lambda Iteration (FBILI), is briefly described and the applications of the method to various RT problems are listed and discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: A physical mechanism of solar corona heating
entry.summary: Time profiles of solar soft X-ray microflares and structure soft X-ray solar corona thermal background are studied on RHESSI data. The observations of 2003 year are analyzed. Decrease fluxe of solar soft X-ray microflares and thermal background of solar corona in the X-ray range 2-15 kev are revealed. The new model of solar corona heating in based on this new data are suggested.

author.name: I. K. Mirzoeva
author.arxiv:affiliation: Space Research Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow

entry.arxiv:comment: e-mail: colombo2006@mail.ru

entry.title: Parent Stars of Extrasolar Planets. XII. Additional evidence for trends with vsini, condensation temperature, and chromospheric activity
entry.summary: Several recent studies have reported differences in vsini, abundance-condensation temperature trends, and chromospheric activity between samples of stars with and without Doppler-detected planets. These findings have been disputed, and the status of these results remains uncertain. We evaluate these claims using additional published data and find support for all three.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 4 figures; accepted for publication in MNRAS as a Letter

entry.title: White Dwarf Model Atmospheres: Synthetic Spectra for Super Soft Sources
entry.summary: The T\"ubingen NLTE Model-Atmosphere Package (TMAP) calculates fully metal-line blanketed white dwarf model atmospheres and spectral energy distributions (SEDs) at a high level of sophistication. Such SEDs are easily accessible via the German Astrophysical Virtual Observatory (GAVO) service TheoSSA. We discuss applications of TMAP models to (pre) white dwarfs during the hottest stages of their stellar evolution, e.g. in the parameter range of novae and super soft sources.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: Does the Babcock--Leighton Mechanism Operate on the Sun?
entry.summary: The contribution of the Babcock-Leighton mechanism to the generation of the Sun's poloidal magnetic field is estimated from sunspot data for three solar cycles. Comparison of the derived quantities with the A-index of the large-scale magnetic field suggests a positive answer to the question posed in the title of this paper.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 2 figures, to apper in Astronomy Letters

entry.title: The long history of the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect and its recent applications
entry.summary: In this paper I will review the Rossiter-McLaughlin (RM) effect; its history, how it manifests itself during stellar eclipses and planetary transits, and the increasingly important role its measurements play in guiding our understanding of the formation and evolution of close binary stars and exoplanet systems.
entry.arxiv:comment: proceedings IAU symposium 282. six pages, two figures, typos corrected

entry.title: Higher-order nonlinear electron-acoustic solitary excitations in partially degenerate quantum electron-ion plasmas
entry.summary: Propagation of dressed solitary excitations are studied in a partially degenerate quantum plasma in the framework of quantum-hydrodynamics (QHD) model using multiple scales technique. The evolution equation together with a linear inhomogeneous differential equation is solved using Kodama-Taniuti renormalizing technique. It is shown that the type of solitary excitations (bright or dark) is defined by two critical plasma parameter values.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in Indian Journal of Physics

entry.title: Physics of stars understood/expected from asteroesismology
entry.summary: What can be learned about the physics of stellar interiors from studying stellar oscillations? This review address the potential to improve our understandings of convective core overshoot and of more general convection-related effects, microscopic diffusion, rotation and magnetic fields, and finally evolution-induced period changes.
entry.arxiv:comment: 14 pages, 1 figure, Proceedings of the 61st Fujihara Seminar: Progress in solar/stellar physics with helio- and asteroseismology, to appear in ASP Conference Series

entry.title: V1162 Orion: Updated Amplitude and Period Variation
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: He-accreting WDs as SNe Ia Progenitors
entry.summary: We investigate the thermal response of CO WDs accreting He-rich matter directly from their companions in binary systems. Our results suggest that the He-channel cannot provide progenitors for majority of "normal" SNe Ia.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 3 figures, contribution to the Proceeding of IAU 281 "Binary Paths to Type Ia Supernovae Explosions"

entry.title: Long Period Variables in the Magellanic Clouds with EROS-2 survey
entry.summary: We use the EROS-2 database to analyze Long Period Variables (LPVs) in the Magellanic Clouds. It results in the creation of a catalog of more than 40 000 LPV candidates which is briefly introduced here.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in the proceedings of the conference "Why Galaxies Care About AGB Stars II", Vienna, August 16-20, 2010, ASP Conference Series

entry.title: Future prospects for inference on solar-type stars
entry.summary: We discuss prospects for asteroseismic inference on solar-type stars, in particular opportunities that are being made possible by the large ensemble of exquisite-quality Kepler data.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, 1 figure. To appear in the ASP proceedings of "The 61st Fujihara seminar: Progress in solar/stellar physics with helio- and asteroseismology", 13th-17th March 2011, Hakone, Japan

entry.title: Symbiotic stars as possible progenitors of SNe Ia: binary parameters and overall outlook
entry.summary: Symbiotic stars are interacting binaries in which the first-formed white dwarf accretes and burns material from a red giant companion. This paper aims at presenting physical characteristics of these objects and discussing their possible link with progenitors of type Ia supernovae.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages. Invited rewiev at "Binary Paths to Type Ia Supernovae", IAU Symposium No. 281, R. Di Stefano & M. Orio, eds., Cambridge University Press

entry.title: Flavor stability analysis of supernova neutrino fluxes compared with simulations
entry.summary: We apply a linearized stability analysis to simplified models of accretion-phase neutrino fluxes streaming from a supernova. We compare the results with recent numerical studies and find excellent agreement. This provides confidence that a linearized stability analysis can be further applied to more realistic models.
entry.arxiv:comment: Contribution to the Proceedings of HANSE 2011 workshop, 4 pages, 2 figures

entry.title: The multifrequency behaviour of the recurrent nova RS Ophiuchi
entry.summary: This review concentrates on the multifrequency behaviour of RS Ophiuchi and in particular during its latest outburst. Confirmation of the 1945 outburst, bipolar outflows and its possible fate as a Type Ia Supernova are discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages, 5 figures, in The Golden Age of Cataclysmic Variables and Related Objects, F. Giovannelli & L. Sabau-Graziati (eds.), Mem. SAIt. 83 N.2 (in press)

entry.title: Disc outbursts in various types of binary systems
entry.summary: I discuss some aspects of the Disc Instability Model applied to outbursts in various types of binary systems. I lament the general lack of interest in the subject.
entry.arxiv:comment: The Golden Age of Cataclysmic Variables and Related Objects, F. Giovannelli & L. Sabau-Graziati (eds.), Mem. SAIt. (2012) 83 N.2 (in press)

entry.title: Variable Stars
entry.summary: This is the triennial report of IAU Commission 27, mostly presenting a review of recent advances in the field.
entry.arxiv:comment: Transactions of the IAU, Volume 28A "Reports on Astronomy", to be published by Cambridge University Press in 2012

entry.title: Spectral Analysis via the Virtual Observatory: The Service Theossa
entry.summary: In the framework of the Virtual Observatory, the newly developed service TheoSSA provides access to theoretical stellar spectral-energy distributions. In a pilot phase, this service is based on the well established Tuebingen NLTE Model-Atmosphere Package for hot, compact stars. We demonstrate its present capabilities and future extensions.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of JENAM-2011, European Week of Astronomy and Space Science, 8 pages, 6 figures

entry.title: Chromospheric activity on the RS Canum Venaticorum stars
entry.summary: Firstly, we review the stellar chromospheric activity in the optical wavelength. Secondly, we introduce our ongoing project of multi-wavelength high--resolution optical observations aimed at studying the chromospheric activity of different RS CVn stars. Finally, we give our future perspectives.

entry.title: Excitation of stellar pulsations
entry.summary: In this review I present an overview of our current understanding of the physical mechanisms that are responsible for the excitation of pulsations in stars with surface convection zones. These are typically cooler stars such as the Delta Scuti stars, and stars supporting solar-like oscillations.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited paper to be published in: Proc. 61st Fujihara Seminar "Progress in solar/stellar physics with helio- and asteroseismology", Shibahashi H., ed., Hakone, 12 pages, 6 figures

entry.title: Astrophysical Models of r-Process Nucleosynthesis: An Update
entry.summary: An update on astrophysical models for nucleosynthesis via rapid neutron capture, the r process, is given. A neutrino-induced r process in supernova helium shells may have operated up to metallicities of ~10^-3 times the solar value. Another r-process source, possibly neutron star mergers, is required for higher metallicities.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, invited talk given at 11th International Symposium on Origin of Matter and Evolution of Galaxies (OMEG11), Wako, Japan

entry.title: The Pulsation Period of the Hot Hydrogen-Deficient Star MV Sgr
entry.summary: MV Sgr is a hot, hydrogen-deficient star which has undergone R CrB fadings. We have used self-correlation analysis and Fourier analysis of CCD V photometry in the AAVSO International Database to identify a period of 8.0 days in this star; the amplitude is about 0.03 mag. The variability is most likely due to pulsation.

entry.title: A geometrical model for polar plumes observed by STEREO SECCH
entry.summary: Solar polar plumes are bright radial rays rooted at the sun's polar areas. They are widely believed to have the structure of expanding tube. A four degree polynomial function was assumed to represent the change of cross section diameter as a function of height and four unknown parameters were calculated with measured average widths of total 31 plumes at 4 heights (1.04$R_s$,1.10$R_s$,1.16$R_s$,1.20$R_s$).

entry.title: Constraints on model atmospheres from complex asteroseismology of the Œ≤Cephei stars
entry.summary: Using the method termed complex asteroseismology, we derive constraints on model atmospheres, in particular, on the NLTE effects. We fit simultaneously pulsational frequencies and the corresponding values of the nonadiabatic complex parameter f for the four \beta Cephei stars: \theta Oph, \nu Eri, \gamma Peg and 12 Lac. The LTE Kurucz models and the BSTAR2006 NLTE models are tested.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages

entry.title: Studying the hybrid pulsator 12 Lacertae: mode identification and complex seismic modelling
entry.summary: We present identification of the mode degree, l, for all observed frequencies of 12 Lac and results of seismic modelling which consists in fitting simultaneously the centroid mode frequencies and the corresponding values of the complex nonadiabatic f-parameter. Effects of chemical composition, opacities, core overshooting and non-LTE atmospheres were taken into account.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure

entry.title: Virtual Spectro, a tool for spectroscopic signatures of plasma
entry.summary: We present here the tool "Virtual Spectro", a post-processor for spectroscopics analysis of hydrodynamic codes. We describe purpose and method of this tool, and the first application to analysis of high energy laser driven radiative shocks.
entry.arxiv:comment: Communication presented at 1st ECLA (European Conference on Laboratory Astrophysics), 26-30 sep. 2011, PARIS, France

entry.title: Asteroseismology of stars on the upper main sequence
entry.summary: I review the properties of pulsators located on the upper main sequence in the HR diagram and discuss asteroseismic inferences on the internal structure of stars of spectral type A and B. Special attention is given to the problem of uncertainties in stellar opacities in modelling.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages, 3 figures, accepted for publication in the proceedings of the 2011 Frank N. Bash Symposium, "New Horizons in Astronomy"

entry.title: MHD simulations of the solar photosphere
entry.summary: We briefly review the observations of the solar photosphere and pinpoint some open questions related to the magnetohydrodynamics of this layer of the Sun. We then discuss the current modelling efforts, addressing among other problems, that of the origin of supergranulation.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 6 figures; 4th French-Chinese Meeting on Solar Physics Understanding Solar Activity: Advances and Challenges, 4th French-Chinese, Nice, France

entry.title: Two new Wolf-Rayet stars in the LMC
entry.summary: We report the discovery of two previously unknown WN3 stars in the Large Magellanic Cloud. Both are bright (15th magnitude), isolated, and located in regions covered in earlier surveys, although both are relatively weak-lined. We suggest that there may be $\mathcal{O}(10)$ remaining undiscovered WNE stars in the LMC.

entry.title: Be Stars: Rapidly Rotating Pulsators
entry.summary: I will show that Be stars are, without exception, a class of rapidly rotating stars, which are in the majority of cases pulsating stars as well, while none of them does possess a large scale (i.e. with significant dipolar contribution) magnetic field.
entry.arxiv:comment: Review talk given at "XX Stellar Pulsation Conference Series: Impact of new instrumentation and new insights in stellar pulsations", Granada, 5-9 September 2011, in press in AIP Conf. Ser

entry.title: On Nuclear Matter Cores and Their Applications
entry.summary: We review recent series of articles considering electromagnetic effects in self-gravitating systems of nuclear matter. The results find their explicit application within the theory of neutron stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, published in the proceeding of the conference, http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ASPC..453..347B

entry.title: Known Galactic field Blazhko stars
entry.summary: A list of known Galactic field stars exhibiting Blazhko effect containing 242 stars is presented. All the entries including their designations, positions, pulsation, and Blazhko periods were collected from the available literature. The actual values of parameters are given.
entry.arxiv:comment: 8 pages, accepted for publication in A&A, corrected typos

entry.title: Pulsar electrodynamics revisited
entry.summary: The inductive electric field is unjustifiably neglected in most models for pulsar electrodynamics; it cannot be screened by the magnetospheric plasma, and it is not small in comparison with the corotation electric field. The perpendicular component of the inductive electric field implies a drift motion that is inconsistent with corotation at any angular velocity. Some implications of the inductive electric field and the associated drift motion are discussed.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages

entry.title: POPCORN: A comparison of binary population synthesis codes
entry.summary: We compare the results of three binary population synthesis codes to understand the differences in their results. As a first result we find that when equalizing the assumptions the results are similar. The main differences arise from deviating physical input.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, Proceedings of the conference: "370 Years of Astronomy in Utrecht"

entry.title: Variable stars in NGC 457
entry.summary: We present preliminary results of the photometric variability search in the field of view of the young open cluster NGC 457. We find over 60 variable stars in the field, including 25 pulsating or candidate pulsating stars.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, 1 figure, 20th Stellar Pulsation Conference Series - Impact of new instrumentation and new insights in stellar pulsations, Granada, 5-9 September 2011

entry.title: Definition of reconnection rate of solar flares registered in 2011-2012 years
entry.summary: Was defined reconnection rate of solar flares observed with the SOHO Michelson Doppler Imager (MDI). Measured physical parameters of 15 flares, such as the temporal scale, size and magnetic flux density. Estimated reconnection inflow velocity, coronal Alfven velocity, and reconnection rate using the observed values.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 1 figure. arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:astro-ph/0605712 by other authors

entry.title: SAGA: Stellar Abundances for Galactic Archaeology
entry.summary: A tutorial for the Stellar Abundances for Galactic Archaeology (SAGA) database is presented. This paper describes the outline of the database, reports the current status of the data compilation and known problems, and presents plans for future updates and extensions.
entry.arxiv:comment: Proceedings of the conference, "Nuclei in the Cosmos XII", invited talk at Online Support session

entry.title: Basic relations for the period variation models of variable stars
entry.summary: Models of period variations are basic tools for period analyzes of variable stars. We introduce phase function and instant period and formulate basic relations and equations among them. Some simple period models are also presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 0 figures, written for Annual Proceendings of Science and Technology at V\v{S}B--TUO

entry.title: On the Periods of Negative Superhumps and the Nature of Superoutbursts
entry.summary: Osaki and Kato (2012) interpreted variations of the negative superhump periods, discovered by them in dwarf nova V1504 Cyg, as evidence in favor of the thermal-tidal instability model for superoutbursts. It is shown that their interpretation was incorrect. The observational evidence is recalled showing that superoutbursts are due to the enhanced mass transfer rate.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages; submitted to "Acta Astronomica"

entry.title: Application of Binary Evolution in Astrophysical Studies
entry.summary: Binary stars evolve differently from single stars, thus binary evolution is very useful for astrophysical studies. This paper discusses the application of binary evolution in the studies of stars, star clusters, galaxies, and cosmology. In particular, I concentrate on the use of binary evolution in colour-magnitude diagram and spectral energy distribution studies of star clusters and galaxies.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, shown in ASPC

entry.title: On the nature of veiling of classical T Tauri stars spectra in the near-IR spectral band
entry.summary: It is shown that the existence of a hot accretion spot on the surface of classical T Tauri stars allows to explain observed veiling of their photospheric spectrum not only in the visible but also in the near infrared spectral band.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 2 figures, accepted for publication in Astronomy Letters

entry.title: Lesson learned from (some) recurrent novae
entry.summary: In this talk we present early decline and nebular spectra of the recurrent novae YY Dor and nova LMC 2009. These and a few other recurrent novae of the same type, share similar spectral characteristics and evolution. We will critically discuss those common features suggesting same white dwarf progenitor and post outburst phases for all of them.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 3 figures -- Stellae novae conference proceeding

entry.title: Elimination of long-term variation from chaotic light curves
entry.summary: We performed a comparative dynamical investigation of chaotic test data using the global flow reconstruction method. We demonstrate that large-amplitude, long-term variations may have a disturbing effect in the analysis. The Empirical Mode Decomposition method (EMD) and the Fourier filtering were tested to remove the additional variations. Test results show that the elimination of these variations significantly increased the robustness of the reconstructions.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages, 6 figures, accepted for publication in AN

entry.title: Forty years of UBV photometry at Hvar
entry.summary: The history of the program of systematic UBV photometric monitoring of Be stars, binaries, CP stars and some other targets is briefly summarized. It is shown that a careful data homogenization, reduction and transformation to the standard Johnson system can be carried out successfully even at a station nearly the sea level when some strict measures are taken.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 4 figures; 11th Hvar Astrophysical Colloquium : The Most Mysterious Binaries: Significance for Astrophysics, Hvar, July 2012

entry.title: Hall Equilibria: Solutions with toroidal and poloidal magnetic fields in Neutron Star Crusts
entry.summary: We present Hall equilibrium solutions for neutron stars crusts containing toroidal and poloidal magnetic field. Some simple cases are solved analytically while more complicated configurations are found numerically through a Gauss-Seidel elliptic partial differential equation solver.
entry.arxiv:comment: Conference Proceedings, Magnetic Fields in the Universe IV (2013)

entry.title: Detection of Coma Activity of the ACO/Quasi-Hilda Object, 212P/2000YN30
entry.summary: The quasi-Hilda object, 212P/2000YN30 with a cometary-like orbit, was found to display a dust tail structure between January and March, 2009. From orbital calculations, it is shown that this object could have been an active comet in its past history before being transported to the current orbital configuration in quasi-stable 3:2 resonance with Jupiter.

entry.title: Modelling the recurrent nova U Scorpii in quiescence
entry.summary: VLT and SALT spectroscopy of U Sco were obtained $\sim$18 and $\sim$30 months after the 2010 outburst. From these spectra the accretion disc is shown to take at least 18 months to become fully reformed. The spectral class of the companion is constrained to be F8$^{+5}_{-6}$\,IV-V at the 95% confidence level when the irradiated face of the companion is visible.

entry.title: Magnetic fields in O stars
entry.summary: Over the last decade, large-scale, organized (generally dipolar) magnetic fields with a strength between 0.1 and 20 kG were detected in dozens of OB stars. This contribution reviews the impact of such magnetic fields on the stellar winds of O-stars, with emphasis on variability and X-ray emission.
entry.arxiv:comment: Invited review at "Putting A-stars into context" (June 2013 ; Moscow, Russia), proceedings of 10 pages

entry.title: Electron Beam Evolution and Radio Emission in the Inhomogeneous Solar Corona
entry.summary: This thesis considers the propagation of accelerated electron beams in plasma. We consider the wave particle interactions these undergo which cause their evolution, the effects of plasma density inhomogeneities on these interactions, and the effects this may have on the production of hard X-ray and radio emission by the beam. ...
entry.arxiv:comment: PhD Thesis, University of Glasgow, 2013

entry.title: Principal Physical Effects in Collapsing Stellar Cores
entry.summary: Principally important for the description the physical processes in the collapsing stellar cores topics are surveyed. They are: the neutrino heat conduction theory, equation of state under the conditions of nuclear statistical equilibrium and possible phase transitions in dense, subnuclear and nuclear environment.
entry.arxiv:comment: Submitted to the Proceedings of the ICRANet workshop "From Nuclei to White Dwarfs and Neutron Stars'', (Les Houches, 3--8 April 2011)

entry.title: Neutrino-induced nucleosynthesis as a result of mixing between the He and C-O-Ne shells in core-collapse supernova
